div.p: From Marcus Clarke
Letter no. 120/I.T.M.71, Outward letterbook 1870-9 pp. 244-245, Industrial and Technological Museum and Public Library, Museum Victoria.

19th July [1871]
editorial addition.
Dear Sir

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; padding-left: 0in; padding-right: 0in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0.0138in; border-left: none; border-right: none; border-top: none; border-bottom: 1.5pt solid #000000;

div.p:
I am directed by the above Committee
The committee of the Industrial Museum, Melbourne. to request that you will be good enough to furnish them with replies to the following queries
The distillation of of Malt Vinegar
1 what is the most approved method?
2 will distillation of Malt Vinegar improve its market value otherwise than by concentrating it?
3 will — in your opinion — such an industry become a profitable one?
The processing bitter from Hore-Hound

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.248in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.248in;

div.p: What is the most approved method

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.248in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.248in;

div.p: From what other plants common in the Colony can a bitter be extracted after the same manner.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.248in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.248in;

div.p:
Could — in your opinion — a still be profitably employed here in processing Essences , & Essential oils , and from what plants would you recommend that the extract be made
M answered these questions in M to M. Clarke, 25 July 1871 (in this edition as 71-07-25c).

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: I have the honor to be
